name: Clément Aubert
content: Clément Aubert — Associate Professor in Computer Science Clément Aubert — Associate Professor in Computer Science Photo courtesy of Brent Cline. More pictures here. Aux visiteurs francophones J’ai un site plus complet et plus orienté recherche à aubert.perso.math.cnrs.fr. La plupart des documents y sont en Anglais et en Français, d’ailleurs. Presentation I am an associate professor (with tenure) in Computer Science at the School of Computer and Cyber Sciences, at Augusta University, in Georgia, USA. I am also a member of the Graduate School and the faculty advisor of the ΔΛΔ. Prior to that, I have been a post-doctoral researcher at the Appalachian State University (Boone, NC, USA), at the LACL (Créteil, Val-de-Marne, France), at the I2M (Marseille, Bouches-du-Rhône, France), and a PhD student at the LIPN (Villetaneuse, Île-de-France, France). Please refer to my resume or my bios for a more complete presentation, and find below information about my teaching, my research, internships and projects, as well as miscellaneous factoids and how to contact me. Teaching Currently (Fall 2025) This semester, I am responsible for CSCI 3400 - Data Structures CSCI 8940 - Dissertation Research (two sections) the Provost Learning Community -- Making the Invisible Visible The ΔΛΔ Programming Languages Reading Group activities will take place on Fridays as usual. Students can have a look at my "Quick Reflection on Course Evaluations", which includes my previous evaluations, to be better prepared for the classes I teach and know what to expect. Notes CSCI 1301 - Principles of Computer Programming I, which is a mirror of the version hosted on github, and has been superseded by princomp.github.io. Research I work in the vast field of computational logic, which uses mathematical reasoning to discover and explain the mechanisms of computation. You might want to have a look at (in decreasing order of preference) an open directory of my publications at dissemin, self-archived research works at HAL and arXiv, my publication list, also hosted at dblp, or at the NIH's Library, my reviewer profile at MathSciNet or at zbMATH, my orcid.org profile, my Mastodon Academy profile, my Semantics Scholar profile, my google scholar profile, my ResearchGate profile (but, please, do not use it, and refer to this post as to why you should refrain from using it), my Pure profile.
